column4: Can anyone help me? During some Linux boots, I end up with a bunch of sprawling code that will end and lead me nowhere after a point. :(
You would have to be more specific as to what the code says.
I believe it says "kernel-init-helper"
this happens when I use the recovery console, and recently when booting Ubuntu, then I get nowhere.
Let me do some googling, one second.
Do you have a prompt that you can use when you boot?
Only a prompt asking me for one of three boot options, and after that it just scrolls through code and would SEEM as if it's waiting for something, but nothing.
Tylermolamphy
What are your three boot options?
boot generic, recovery boot, and go back for my Win7 option.
This would be a lot easier if I had the actual error that you are getting. Could you maybe boot up and give me the last few lines of code on your screen?
That is the last line, something about the kernel help but along with that there's that line, and one with a ? at the beginning, like that for hundreds of lines too. Not just that one.
That's a bit confusing. What specifically does it say about your kernel? If it is a kernel issue and it's not giving you a prompt, it's usually cause for a re-installation of the kernel.
That would make a bit of sense, because I can't get anywhere when it comes down to that, but it would seem that another copy of "Isadora" does just about the same.
I would try reinstalling Mint, but if a fresh installation throws this error at you, then it's either a bad kernel release (unlikely,) or it doesn't like your computer hardware (more likely.)
I'm not familiar what kernel Mint runs on, so from there you're about on your own.
I'd take your advice for both, ubuntu didn't have my drivers and although I got around that, Mint has disagreed from the start.

Try out a new flavor, like Ubuntu 10.10 or Kubuntu 10.10, and see if you still have the same problems. Then you'll know that it's your hardware, unless Mint and Ubuntu run the same kernel. I have no idea if they do or not.
Ubuntu 10.10 is what I'm using, but I'll give a reinstall a shot.
Tylermolamphy
When you said Isadora, I assumed you were running Linux Mint. My bad.
In that case, try 10.04 and see if those issues are there.
They run different kernels.
